ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course helped me develop individual paper writing and development skills amid an immersive seminar - how to develop a single line of research and thought while moving on to others in the class itself.
A keen insight into modern and historical philosophical skepticism.

In Skepticism with Professor Della Rocca, I learned about several different kinds of skepticism throughout the history of philosophy. For example, we read ancient authors, Chinese and Buddhist writers, as well as Renaissance and Early Modern skeptics. I really liked the readings and how MDR would break down each type for us as a class and draw connections between them. I think I definitely learned more about skepticism and find myself making skeptical arguments in conversation sometimes (it is a fun party topic in my opinion -- like, how do I know I'm not dreaming right now? How do I know my senses tell me the truth about things?). Also, there are two papers, so I did improve my philosophy writing, especially because we had to write a longer piece..

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: MDR is awesome, and an amazing teacher and presence. I think at times we maybe could have benefited from handouts, and at times other seminar members would go on tangents when I frankly wanted to hear Michael just lecture, but the discussions were generally great.

It is a good overview of skepticism throughout history. I like how the course covered different philosophers such as Zhuangzi, Nagarjuna and Sextus rather than just covering traditional western philosophers. Della Rocca created a great environment for discussion and explains difficult concepts very eloquently.

This course was a lot of fun! We met once weekly for about two hours and the discussions were always very interesting. The course was made up of undergraduates (mostly junior and senior philosophy majors), as well as some divinity students and philosophy PhD students, and for me (an undergraduate) I found it valuable to hear from the graduate students as they were all very smart and insightful. Also, MDR is a wonderful teacher and human being: very understanding and very enjoyable to learn under. He has a knack for explaining complex arguments in simple terms, and gives very useful feedback on papers. He actually received a Sterling professorship as he was teaching this course which was very cool. I enjoyed writing my final paper and I thought the course was overall very strong..

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another philosophy student interested in exploring skepticism at length or in questioning their beliefs. I think the class might be too much for someone new to philosophy, but for an upper level undergrad it is perfect
Yes! Professor Della Rocca is one of a kind.
Yes. Great topic and great teaching.

I very much enjoyed Skepticism and would recommend to other students, especially junior and senior philosophy majors interested in epistemology. I feel like I learned a lot, and many of the discussions and readings will stay with me after this semester. Professor Della Rocca is absolutely wonderful and I recommend everyone interested in philosophy to take a course with him at some point. My favorite authors we read were Sextus and Descartes, and I also enjoyed the small taste of Chinese philosophy we receive with guest Prof. Hunter. It was nice to have graduate students present on topics they were particularly knowledgeable about, and I liked having the graduate students in class because I learned a lot from hearing the ways they were thinking about the texts. This class was definitely challenging for me and probably the most difficult course I've taken so far in my major, but it was absolutely worth it..
